text: the desperate scene as mothers fathers
brothers and sisters arrive at the
school where more than 200 girls were
abducted this footage which has just
emerged captures the awful moments last
week when they visited the burnt-out
shell in chibok all that remains of the
place from where their girls were taken
we want to let the world know that we
don't feel Nigeria can help us get our
daughters back we're not happy with the
way the Nigerian government has handled
this issue the girls are now thought to
have been dispersed into smaller groups
perhaps taken over to neighboring
countries to a believed to have already
died from snakebite a few did escape and
a campaigner who met them told the BBC
about what she'd learnt the girls went
to a horrifying experience they were
terrorized they were made to believe
that even their family members come
after them their family members will be
killed and they would not in any way be
returned back protests in the capital
Abuja anger growing over the
government's slow and haphazard response
a view echoed by one veteran African
diplomat I think the reaction of Africa
should have been
faster and they should have come out
condemning this very very actively I
also believe that the Nigerian
government should have shared a bit more
with his own population the girls were
taken by the violent Islamist group Boko
Haram whose leader in this video said he
intended to sell them the global
campaign for the girls release has been
growing on the streets and on social
media it's been joined by Malala
yousufzai the Pakistani girl attacked by
the Taliban for going to school she
talked to the BBC here in Britain Waku
haram is in there it's their extremist
and they don't really understand Islam
because Islam says that it is your duty
to get education so they cannot deny
this fact hopes for these parents that
their daughters may be released soon are
fading and today new reports of more
violence with hundreds killed by Boko
Haram in the same region gordon carrera
BBC news
